Posts.Content: Jan50 wrote: Ow, ow, ow!  After a short run with Estradiol, after which I ended up in the hospital with a bad case of hypercalcemia, I'm home on respite with no meds other than potassium supplements. So my only problem at the moment is severe muscle aches and stiffness. I had been taking Darvocet alternating with Ibuprofen, but they don't seem that effective. Same with Oxycodone...nothing. It's true that I'm still recovering from a hospital stay, but this muscle thing comes and goes. One day I'm only a little stiff when I walk, others I can hardly move. Anyone have this? Does anything help...meds, supplements, exercise? Jan Original dx 2000, Stage IV dx 2005, bone and skin mets, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Xeloda Hopeful101 LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 06:22AM Jan50 wrote: I'm with you, JoJo! I applaud your courage in speaking up about your convictions. I also refused any treatment after my original dx in 2000 and was fine until bone mets dx in 2005. I then agreed to try hormonals and had a couple of rounds of radiation to zap some pesky tumors in inconvenient places. I'm now taking Xeloda, but that's my limit. When my quality of life starts to become compromised, and it's almost to that point, I'm going to let it go. I don't like the metaphor of battle, especially with parts of myself. I don't see cancer as my enemy. Having said that, I do understand it's a personal decision and I would support women who choose to have extended treatment, as long as they know it's a choice. But my children are grown, I'm at the height of my career, and I've achieved all my personal goals. Enough is enough!

I agreed to try it because it is an oral med with minimal side effects (at least so far for me). The skin mets have not changed but my TMs went down. I'm having a bone scan this week, so that will tell if X is working in my bones or not.

Posts.Title: Anyone on Estradiol? Jan50 RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 09:40AM Jan50 wrote: Hi Marianne, I'm sorry you are having so much trouble with your skull mets. I have mets there along with others in my arms, legs, ribs, spine...you name it, they're everywhere. But the only specific treatment I had for the skull was some focused radiation on one tumor that threatened to push on something important in my brain. But that took care of it and I haven't had any other problems except some numbness in my chin which can also be related to skull mets. Other than that, I just take medication to keep the cancer in check anywhere it happens to appear.
Posts.Title: skull mets mreilley mreilley

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 08:10AM Jan50 wrote: There is another thread about this on the Just Diagnosed With Mets forum. Here's what I posted there: I never heard of skin mets until I got them, and even my family doc took a look and said it was nothing. But the onc recognized them immediately and ordered a biopsy to confirm. Mine are small, solid bumps under the skin. I have two on my back that are red and smaller one near my front clavicle that is skin-colored. The positive thing about this is that they can be used as markers to see if the medication I'm on (Xeloda) is working. I have bone mets that can't be seen, so we just watch the skin mets to see what they do between bone scans.
Posts.Title: Skin Mets donnaakadj Bmarie

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2009 06:12AM Jan50 wrote: Bmarie...do you have to get rid of them? As I mentioned in another post above, my onc uses my skin mets as markers to make sure the Xeloda is holding. As long as they are not growing, we assume things are OK. She's never said anything about removing them. But I only have three, and they don't itch or cause pain, so maybe it's different for me.

Posts.Content: May 15, 2009 12:58PM Jan50 wrote: My doctor turned chicken (her description) and bailed on Faslodex after six months. My TMs were climbing and, while the bone scan showed major improvement in most places, there were a couple of suspicious areas that appeared to be growing. So now I'm on Xeloda, the TMs are down, and I'm scheduled for another bone scan next month.
Posts.Title: Faslodex...how long should I give it? saw1019 LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2009 07:14AM Jan50 wrote: A few months ago, I experienced a severe drop in hemoglobin which my onc saw as an indication of mets in my bone marrow, but she didn't push a bone marrow biopsy just to confirm what already seemed evident. I had two blood transfusions in March, and I had just started Xeloda for my extensive bone mets, so we decided to wait and see what would happen. Since then, my hemoglobin started rising on its own and my other blood counts are good. Maybe it's the Xeloda working. But my point is that I'm glad I didn't panic and rush into more extensive treatment for the blood marrow issue. While I wouldn't presume to give any advice on your situation, I can just say that I would get a second opinion before compromising my quality of life if it's not absolutely necessary.
Posts.Title: Results of Bone Marrow biopsy received kenzie57 Jan50

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 11:20AM Jan50 wrote: I've had bone mets for over three years. When I suddenly developed severe anemia this spring, my onc suspected the cancer had moved into the bone marrow and was suppressing my body's ability to make red blood cells. We didn't do any further testing, however, because it wouldn't have affected my treatment. We're throwing Xeloda at it, and it's either going to work or it's not. I had two blood transfusions in March, and my blood count just recently started coming up on its own. I don't go looking for trouble with more tests than necessary. I just don't want to know. Denial has worked well for me so far.

Posts.Content: May 20, 2009 01:16PM Jan50 wrote: I was on a monthly schedule of Zometa for two years, then once every three months for the last year and a half. The explanation for backing off was that Zometa was never tested for long-term use and the concern was continued benefit versus possible toxicity after a period of time. My onc said she would consider backing off to once every six months if I am still going strong at the five-year mark. But now I'm confused whether Zometa is supposed to cause bone and muscle pain or relieve it. I'll admit I've had more problems since backing off. However, I'm also told that the pain could be the result of tumor flare and an indicator that healing is taking place. So it's either getting better or getting worse, but they don't know which. For some reason, I find that funny!
Posts.Title: How often do you get Zometa infusion? meima-Bev marieibrahim

Posts.Content: May 22, 2009 03:32PM Jan50 wrote: I had severe back pain for a month or so before it even occurred to me to mention it to my onc. She sent me for an MRI that day and by the end of the week I was receiving radiation for a tumor pressing on my spinal chord. The radiation doc was quite clear that the tumor needed to be shrunk before it caused permanent damage. That was over a year ago and I've had no pain since and no side effects from the radiation. Best decision I ever made.
Posts.Title: ? for rads to bone mets....... saint saint

Posts.Content: May 24, 2009 09:32AM Jan50 wrote: Saint...I wish you the best. Trusting your doctor is the first step. While I certainly don't want to minimize some of the problems other women have had with radiation, I can speak from experience with the three rounds I have had. The worst thing for me was taking the steroids...I ate everything in sight and my face started to swell after a week or so. But I survived a very concentrated and specific zapping to two spots in my skull and, a couple of years later, a more generalized round to a tumor pressing on my spinal cord and another round to stabilize my hip. All treatments were short, easy, and solved the immediate problems. Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: ? for rads to bone mets....... saint saint

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2009 12:32PM Jan50 wrote: Analemma...I think whatever choice you made is the best one for you. I wouldn't go back and second guess anything. I was amused, though, by the difference of opinion between the rad onc and med onc, because the same thing happened to me. I have three areas of skin mets that the rad onc offered to zap, but the med onc wants to keep as indicators to see if Xeloda is working. So far they are holding steady, and I just had a bone scan (no results yet) to see if my bone mets are also stable. But I read in a recent post where one woman's skin mets stayed the same while her liver mets went crazy, so maybe the theory of using one area of cancer as a marker for another is faulty. I am left believing that no one really knows!
